Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Climate change and birds: links among earlier nesting, migratory strategies, and warmer winters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change effects on the timing of breeding seasons have been well documented for many bird species. Birds may breed earlier because warmer spring temperatures cause earlier plant growing seasons and, consequently, insect prey becomes more abundant earlier in the year. In southwest Idaho, American kestrels are breeding almost a month earlier than they did 20 years ago; however, spring temperatures and plant growing seasons have not changed significantly during that time period. One explanation is that more individuals are spending the winter on or near their breeding ground. If so, it is important to understand the fitness consequences of this shift in behavior. This project will examine whether kestrels that remain on the breeding area year-round 1) nest earlier in the year, 2) obtain better territories or 3) produce more offspring, compared to kestrels that leave the breeding area for the winter. While many studies have suggested how climate change may negatively affect bird populations, in this system, milder winters may be resulting in more year-round residency, earlier breeding, and potentially, population stability or growth.

This project will promote partnerships among community members, including private landowners, universities, and local non-profits. It will also provide education and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students while supporting an early-career female researcher. Results from this project will be relevant for nationwide bird monitoring programs and management plans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to understand why animals are breeding earlier in response to climate change.  We addressed two main hypotheses: 1) animals breed earlier because warmer winters create changes in the non-breeding season that have carry-over effects on the timing of breeding, and 2) animals breed earlier to synchronize raising their offspring with peak food abundance, which is now available earlier because of earlier growing seasons associated with climate change. Our study system was a population of American Kestrels (Falco sparverius) that nest in southwestern Idaho in a mix of irrigated agriculture and shrub and grassland habitats.  In our study area, American Kestrels are partial migrants, meaning that some Kestrels migrate while others remain in the nesting area year-round.  Over the past 24 years, winter temperatures have warmed significantly and, in that same time period, the average American kestrel nest initiation dates have advanced. To address the hypothesis that warmer winters have carry-over effects on the timing of breeding, we followed color-banded Kestrels across their whole annual cycle. We found that, in most years, Kestrels that did not migrate (and over-wintered in our study area) nested earlier than Kestrels that nested in local boxes, but were not observed in our study area during winter (presumably, because these birds migrated).  These results support the hypotheses that as winters warm and the proportion of Kestrels that remain on the breeding ground increases (or migration distances shorten), the timing of breeding is likely to advance. To address the second hypothesis, that earlier breeding is driven by earlier prey abundance, we estimated shifts in the timing of prey abundance over the period of our long-term Kestrel data.  We did this by analyzing satellite images of our study area from 1992-2015 to score the greenness of plants and determine the start of the growing season for each year because the amount of prey available to Kestrels increases with plant productivity.  We did this for both agricultural and non-irrigated shrub/grasslands in our study area.  We found that growing season onset on agricultural lands has advanced by about three weeks since 1992, while growing season onset on non-irrigated lands has not changed.  We also found a strong, positive association between the timing of kestrel nesting and growing season onset in agricultural plots. Earlier growing seasons in agriculture were driven by earlier planting of crops after warm winters, not by increasing spring temperatures. In fact, spring temperatures stayed the same, which was reflected by the absence of a temporal trend in growing season onset in shrub/grasslands. By measuring more than just the climatic variable of temperature, and by measuring growing season onset for different land cover types, it became clear that it was the human response to climate change (earlier planting in warmer winters) that was driving the biological change of earlier growing seasons, which kestrels responded to directly by shifting nest initiation dates earlier in the season.  

This study demonstrates the many factors that influence when animals breed and highlights that as human systems begin to shift in response to climate change, understanding the relationships between alterations in both climate and human activity will become increasingly important.
